oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Studio portrait of Dora Corrine Adams Johnson, circa 1910s or 1920s
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white copy photograph of a studio portrait of Dora Corinne Adams Johnson seated at an angle. Photograph appears to be made in the late 1910s or early 1920s. Dora Corinne Adams Johnson (1882-1952) was the daughter of Samuel Adams and Elmirah Adams. Samuel Adams was born into slavery in South Carolina and Elmirah is belived to be a Native American. Dora Corinne Adams Johnson was born in 1882, and was a member of St. James CME in Collierville, Tennessee, a church founded by her father. She later attended Mt. Pisgah CME in Orange Mound, Memphis, Tennessee. At both churches she acted as a Stewardess, assisting in giving communion during church services. She died in 1952 and is buried at St. James CME Church Cemetery in Collierville, Tennessee.

Portraiture was a highly political activity for African Americans, especially after Emancipation. Frederick Douglass considered photography the most democratic of arts and a crucial aid in African Americans' quest to achieve citizenship because it served as a potent equalizer. Early photographs of African Americans are linked to the first phase of a way of thinking defined as Racial Uplift: an ideology which emphasized education, achievement, and propriety as marks of personal distinction that would refute racist stereotypes and establish a basis for positive black identities. Photography became the way African Americans visually documented their efforts for full citizenship and political enfranchisement.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Johnson, Dora Corrine Adams, 1882-1952
